text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today i have a 
recipe to share with you that is a classic dish

of northern thailand with a very fun name gaeng 
ho so ha in the northern thai dialect means a

mix of stuff and the reason it's called that is 
because it started out with people just throwing

together some leftovers and turning it into a new 
dish so typically this would be a leftover curry

called gaeng hung lay which is a northern curry and 
then they throw in a bunch of vegetables and they

add glass noodles and then they turn it into 
basically a glass noodle stir-fry flavored by

gang hungley but today i'm going to share with you 
how you can make this dish without having to have

leftover gang hang lay so you know you don't have 
to go and make gang hungry first so we're going to

create the flavor right here all right let's get 
started so even though theoretically this is a

mish-mash of whatever leftovers you have you can 
change up the vegetables change up the curry the

one thing that you have to have in order for it 
to be at gaeng ho is glass noodles okay so today

i am once again using pine brand glass noodles 
who is the sponsor of today's episode and if

you've been following the show you know this is 
my favorite brand because it is made from 100

mung bean starch and that's important in glass 
noodles because it gives you the best texture and

it will be the most resistant to overcooking and 
it's a really versatile noodle all you have to do

is soak it in just room temperature water and let 
it soak for seven to ten minutes but if it goes

longer no big deal until it's soft and pliable 
like this okay and you want to cut them otherwise

when come serving time it'll be really long and 
really difficult and i like to cut them into

three different sections and i know some people 
say oh you cut noodles it's bad luck well not

in thailand i want to add also that because 
the noodles come neatly organized like this

when you're draining and soaking it don't toss it 
and mix it up because then you have a hard time

like cutting them into into sections right then 
everything's kind of mixed up i want to give you

a quick tip as well if you for whatever reason are 
ready to cook and you realize you've forgotten to

soak all you have to do is just turn your tap 
water to the hottest that it can go and soak it

in a lot of that hot tap water and it only take 
one to two minutes before it's soft enough for

you to cut again and then for protein i'm gonna 
go with pork belly you can use whatever but i

use pork belly because it is typically the protein 
in gang hang lay right and i got lazy and i bought

the hot pot pork belly that's been pre-sliced 
but you can you can use whatever protein you want

i'm gonna just marinate this a little bit with 
some soy sauce just so the pork has some flavor

and because the pork is thinly sliced it's a 
little hard to separate them gonna just add a

little bit of oil just to help them slide apart 
a little bit more i'm just gonna mix that up

so that's that let me wash my hands and 
i'll go through all the other ingredients

so how we're going to create gang heng lei flavor 
is in our curry paste so i'm going to start out

with red curry paste as a base you can use store 
bought you can make your own i have a recipe for

that i'll link to it and red curry paste is a good 
base curry paste from which you can build other

flavors okay and to make it hang lay flavor i'm 
going to add hungley curry powder which is just

a mix of spices that i do have a recipe for i'll 
link to but you can also for a lazy version just

buy store-bought garam masala and use that as 
well and also genghang lei uses some ginger so

i've got some finely julienne ginger in there as 
well and this right here is how i'm going to get

that hungley flavor so the spirit of this dish is 
that you can use whatever vegetables that you have

sitting around but i want to show you some classic 
thai vegetables that people add into gang ho okay

and you can use this if you have it and just use 
carrots if you don't have it so thai eggplant

is a really classic thing people add and they're 
these beautiful round firm eggplant they're great

in curries great in stir fries because they're 
a little firmer so they don't mush the same way

japanese or globe eggplant will and then for this 
i'm going to just do slices because i'm going to

stir fry it quickly it's not going to have a lot 
of time to cook the other vegetable that's very

common is long beans i couldn't actually find 
long beans so what i did find is even better

fresh baby corn so fresh baby corn is something 
that we use a lot in thai cuisine but for whatever

reason people just don't use it here like there's 
corn all over the place but people don't buy fresh

baby corn um but i scored them at the asian 
store so i just wanted to use them here and

they're great vegetables to use for this because 
they're firm and crunchy they're just so good and

so much better than the canned or frozen ones and 
then you also want to have some leafy vegetables

some something sturdier so i got some wild 
beetle leaves or by tabloo which is also

used a lot in genghou but you can do swiss chard 
you can do sort of chinese broccoli leaves any

leafy greens that's a little sturdy so not like 
baby spinach just gonna you know disappear oh

and they have such a unique aroma that's kind 
of earthy oh there's just here adam smell this

and tell me what it smells like so unique right 
you can't really describe it you can't compare

it to anything apart from that i've got some 
sliced lemongrass and macaroon lime leaves

that i'm gonna add at the end for that fresh 
flavor and that's it we're ready to cook all right

so i've got a wok here i'm gonna preheat 
it i'm gonna add just a little bit of oil

not too much because i am cooking the pork 
belly first which has a lot of fat in itself

so you know me i like to cook off my protein 
separately just because then i can control how

done they are they're not overcooked oh yeah we 
got a little bit of nice browning at the bottom

very nice so all that's done and 
you want this fully cooked because

we're not really going to cook this again so 
i'll turn this off get that out of the pan

and now with what's left that's delicious pork 
fat that i'm going to use to saute my curry paste

but i'm not turning the heat back on because 
i'm adding dry spices and dry spices can burn

very quickly so if your pan is too hot you add 
the dry spices and they can instantly burn so

i'm just gonna leave it off take my time adding 
my things my hungley powder my ginger and then i

turn the heat back on to gently heat everything 
get that mixed up okay and now we turn that on

just on medium not too high if it's starting 
to stick a little bit you want to deglaze

with some water man this stove does not do 
low heat very well there you want to saute

that until it's really aromatic okay 
so now the cur that is spicy smelling

and it smells so good now i'm going to 
add my vegetables my firm vegetables

by the way if you have some chicken stock lying 
around use that instead of water for extra flavor

give that a toss and these just need a few 
minutes to cook and if it's getting a little

dry you can add that little extra water now 
there's one more vegetable that is so classic

in gang ho it's really hard to find but i actually 
managed to find it and i really wanted to show you

but i forgot to bring it oh well what i'm talking 
about is pickle bamboo shoot or rather fermented

bamboo shoot so sour bamboo shoots um if you 
want to use it just check out the written

recipe there's a little bit of prep that goes into 
getting them ready for use so now at this point

you want the eggplant to be you know it obviously 
depends what kind of vegetable you're using you

want to get it sort of like halfway cooked this 
is when you want to go with the noodle so i'm

going to add my noodles and a little bit of water 
because the noodles do need a little extra water

to cook i'm going to add some fish sauce as 
a seasoning some sugar which may look like

a lot of sugar but trust me once it's 
all done it's not actually going to be

a sweet tasting dish but there's a lot of 
salty spicy stuff right now that the sugar

is really needed for balance so let that 
cook until the noodles absorb the liquid

and become translucent and tender which glass 
noodles only take a couple minutes this is why

i love glass noodles they cook so quick they're 
quick to prep so versatile and adam is about to

pass out from chile fumes but what else is new 
so once the noodles are almost done i'm gonna

go in with my bite shapu because even though it's 
a leafy green it's a little sturdier and they do

take a little bit more time to soften 
oh my goodness oh this is gonna be spicy

okay i'm gonna add my pork back in to give 
it a chance to absorb all the flavor oh yes

and just as you're about to finish i'm going to 
turn off the heat and add my fresh lemongrass

and lime leaves and those things are gonna 
add just that bright freshness to counteract

sort of the rich warm spices that we've got 
going on in here oh my my my my and that's it

how quick and easy was that see that's 
the spirit of this dish got a bunch of

leftovers you throw it together next thing you 
know you got food okay oops get back here oh

if you could only be here to smell this 
amazing dish the smell of all those spices

and all the herbs in the red curry paste and if 
you do have the bamboo shoots you will get that

distinct bamboo aroma as well which not everybody 
likes like my husband really does not like that so

when i make things at home i don't add the 
bamboo or i add it and then he complains about it

look at that now if this looks a little drab 
you can always add some chilies on top and make

it even spicier than it already is there you go 
fresh chilies fix all presentation problems now

even though this is noodles you want to serve 
this with rice because trust me that is a very

strong flavor it's not something you want to 
eat a whole bowl of and in the north this would

typically be served with sticky rice but jasmine 
rice would work just fine yes this is a carbon

carb situation but glass noodles actually is 
one of the lowest glycemic noodles out there

so it's actually not that bad and we usually 
serve glass noodle dishes with rice all the time
oh i didn't get any thai eggplant there we go

you gotta have to thai eggplant all right 
make sure i have some pork some corn

definitely some noodles a little bit of rice 
some beetle leaves a little bit of everything

oh it's so aromatic because of 
all those spices that we added

if that is not one of the most flavorful 
dishes i've ever had then i don't know what

is there is so much going on the flavor of 
the curry paste is already lot and add all

of those spices and ah it's just it's it's a 
lot of flavor but it all works together really

well like it's not too much and the crunch 
of the vegetables the baby corn everything

man this is an experience you've got to try 
another thing that came into mind when i ate this

was that this tastes very thai like this is one 
of those dishes that when you eat it it's like

unmistakably thai flavor and the noodles even 
though it's noodles and rice it's not too much

because class noodles are so light and they've got 
this really fun texture that it just really works

and that is it i hope you give this a try the 
recipe as always will be on hatthaikitchen.com

and when you make it you can send me a 
photo on facebook twitter or instagram

and if you haven't subscribed to the show make 
sure you do so you don't miss an awesome recipe

like this and click the bell icon as well so 
you get a notification when i post a new video

thank you as always for watching and i will see 
you next time for your next delicious thai meal
